title: NASA advisers say the SpaceX new technology could put lives at risk
contents: When Elon Musk and his team at SpaceX were looking to make their Falcon 9 rocket even more powerful,  they came up with a creative idea — keep the propellant at super-cold temperatures to shrink its size,  allowing them to pack more of it into the tanks.

But the approach comes with a major risk,  according to some safety experts. At those extreme temperatures,  the propellant would need to be loaded just before takeoff — while astronauts are aboard. An accident,  or a spark,  during this maneuver,  known as "load-and-go, " could set off an explosion.
Elon Musk's flare have collided with a bureaucratic system at NASA that has been accused of being overly conservative in the wake of two shuttle disasters that killed 14 astronauts.

In a recent speech,  Robert Lightfoot,  the former acting NASA administrator,  lamented in candid terms how the agency,  with society as a whole,  has become too risk-averse,  saying: "I wonder,  if Buzz Aldrin and Neil Armstrong would have ever been able to go to the moon in the risk environment we have today."
